intro: Acacia mutabilis subsp. incurva, commonly known as the variable wattle, is a shrub native to South Africa. It is characterized by its distinctive, feathery, yellow flowers that appear in spring. The plant has compound leaves with small, paired leaflets and produces long, thin pods that contain seeds. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in coastal and mountainous regions. The species is known for its rapid growth and adaptability to various environmental conditions.

This subspecies is found in the southern regions of the state, particularly in the southwestern and central areas. It typically grows in sandy soils and is commonly associated with coastal and inland heathlands. The plant is well adapted to the arid and semi-arid climates of its native range. It is an important component of the local flora and contributes to the ecological diversity of the region.
